headline.print_headline: Obesity Studies Tell Two Stories, Both Right
headline.main: Obesity Studies Tell Two Stories, Both Right

docs.abstract: Study published in Journal of the American Medical Association presents data that conflicts with research showing that childhood obesity among young children has fallen since 2004; differing results have prompted scientists to debate whether obesity is declining or not.
docs.lead_paragraph: A new study disputes findings that obesity among young children has declined, but because both sets of research used different time frames, both may be right.
docs.snippet: A new study disputes findings that obesity among young children has declined, but because both sets of research used different time frames, both may be right.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

headline.print_headline: Surge in Narcotic Prescriptions for Pregnant Women
headline.main: Surge in Narcotic Prescriptions for Pregnant Women

docs.abstract: Research published in journal Obstetrics & Gynecology shows that doctors are prescribing painkillers to pregnant women in astonishing numbers, with nearly 23 percent of pregnant women filling opioid prescriptions in 2007, up from 18.5 percent in 2000; risks to developing fetus are largely unknown, raising concern among many health providers.
docs.lead_paragraph: More pregnant women are being prescribed opioid painkillers, whose risks to fetuses are unknown, a move that surprises some doctors and researchers.
docs.snippet: More pregnant women are being prescribed opioid painkillers, whose risks to fetuses are unknown, a move that surprises some doctors and researchers.
